title: UniArray: Unified Spectral-Spatial Modeling for Array-Geometry-Agnostic Speech Separation
author: Weiguang Chen (Hunan University), Junjie Zhang (Hunan University), Jielong Yang (Jiangnan University), Eng Siong Chng (Nanyang Technological University), Xionghu Zhong (Hunan University), ...
relevance_why: The paper addresses array-geometry-agnostic speech separation, which could enhance Haohe Liu's work in speech restoration and source separation, as it provides insights on effectively leveraging spatial information alongside spectral features.
background: Array-geometry-agnostic speech separation aims to successfully separate overlapping speech signals from mixtures recorded by microphone arrays with varying configurations and numbers of microphones.
contribution: UniArray introduces a novel approach with virtual microphone estimation, feature extraction and fusion, and a hierarchical dual-path separator to improve speech separation accuracy across diverse microphone setups.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing methods primarily rely on fixed array geometries and exhaustive permutation techniques, which can limit performance and increase complexity.
technical_comparison.novelty: UniArray models spectral and spatial features more effectively without interleaving processes, capturing dependencies across time and frequency while reducing computational overhead.

key_innovation: The use of a virtual microphone estimation technique combined with hierarchical processing enhances spatial resolution and separation performance across various array configurations.
real_world_impact: This work could significantly improve real-time speech applications, such as telecommunications and automatic speech recognition, by enabling better separation in practical deployment scenarios.

new_terms.array-geometry-agnostic: **Array-geometry-agnostic** refers to techniques that function effectively regardless of the spatial configuration of microphones used in audio capture.
new_terms.virtual microphone estimation (VME): **Virtual microphone estimation (VME)** is a method to enhance spatial resolution by generating simulated microphone signals from real microphone inputs.
